information: National polling data from late April 2025 indicates voting intentions place Reform UK at approximately 25%, Labour at 24%, and the Conservative Party at 22%. Reports suggest the Liberal Democrats are targeting Conservative-held areas with significant campaign resources, and the rise of Reform UK is expected to split the traditional Conservative vote.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 12–14 days (election on 2 May 2025; results expected by 3 May)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — Conservatives currently hold by far the most seats from the 2021 all-out election.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Labour sweeps most Northampton town wards and gains in suburban/fringe areas, while Liberal Democrats flip multiple South Northamptonshire and Daventry rural wards from the Conservatives; Reform UK fields enough candidates to split the right-of-centre vote, pushing Conservatives into second place overall.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Conservatives retain dominance across rural South Northamptonshire and much of Daventry, while opposition gains in Northampton town and select rural pockets are split between Labour and the Liberal Democrats; Reform UK stands patchily, limiting its impact. Result: no overall control, but Conservatives remain the largest party by seat count.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline matters: in 2021 the Conservatives won a large majority in West Northamptonshire, giving them a substantial cushion. To fall behind, they would need to lose heavily in Northampton town and also shed many rural seats to the Lib Dems/Independents, with Reform UK splitting their vote widely across wards. That is possible, but not the default. Geography helps the Conservatives: rural South Northants and much of Daventry are structurally favourable, and multi-member wards can still return multiple Conservatives even with reduced vote shares. 

Countervailing forces are real. The national environment is poor for the Conservatives; 2021 was a high-water mark likely to unwind. The research assistant notes: (1) late-April national vote intention has Conservatives around 22% with Reform at ~25% and Labour ~24%, implying meaningful right-of-centre vote-splitting risk; (2) Liberal Democrats are targeting Conservative-held areas with resources. Both pressures could chip away at the Conservative seat tally from two directions (Labour in the town; Lib Dems in the rural/market towns). However, local elections differ from Westminster polls: Reform often fields incomplete slates and underperforms headline national figures, reducing the scale of the split in practice. Also, Labour’s capacity to convert votes into rural seats is limited; where Conservatives falter outside Northampton, Lib Dems are often the primary beneficiaries rather than Labour, which can still leave the Conservatives as the largest group overall even if they lose their majority.

Why not higher than my estimate: the 2021 baseline advantage could erode sharply in an anti-Conservative cycle, and a coordinated Lib Dem push plus a meaningful Reform presence would make it easier for Labour to finish first by dominating Northampton and picking up some fringes. Why not lower: Conservatives’ structural strength in rural wards, incumbency, and likely patchy Reform presence make it plausible they remain the largest party even amid sizeable losses. 

What would move me up: evidence that Reform UK is running few candidates locally; full Conservative slates versus incomplete opposition slates; strong incumbent restanding rates and local polling/canvass returns showing Conservatives holding rural vote; signs of Labour–Lib Dem competition in the same wards. What would move me down: confirmation that Reform UK has widespread coverage across the council area; credible reports of strong Lib Dem advances in South Northants/Daventry plus Labour dominance in Northampton; defections/scandals hurting Conservatives; ward-level candidate shortfalls for the Conservatives.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Conservative Party win the most seats in the 2025 West Northamptonshire Council election?

Question background:
BBC: [A guide to Northamptonshire's local elections 2025](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cx2g80vme52o)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Conservative Party controls the most seats following the [2025 West Northamptonshire Council election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_West_Northamptonshire_Council_election)




Your research assistant's report says:
National polling data from late April 2025 indicates voting intentions place Reform UK at approximately 25%, Labour at 24%, and the Conservative Party at 22%. Reports suggest the Liberal Democrats are targeting Conservative-held areas with significant campaign resources, and the rise of Reform UK is expected to split the traditional Conservative vote.

Today is 2025-04-21.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
